occurrences.text: life, and we think about the truth that he gives us at the end of the verse, he says, this is not of the Father, but is of the world. It's of the world. Turn back to the book of Genesis once again. We were in Genesis looking at this… progression, but I want you to go to Genesis 3, a familiar portion of Scripture for many of us this morning, and we know this as being the account in which the Bible records for us the fall of man when sin entered into the world. And I want you to see that in this very passage of Scripture, that the lust of the flesh, the lust of the eyes, and the pride of life is all contained. We find that here oftentimes as we look at this passage of Scripture, perhaps we are mindful of what takes place and we're familiar with the account, but we must recognize this morning that the enemy still uses the same approach. The lust of the flesh, the lust of the eyes, and the pride of life. Notice in verse number one, now the serpent was more subtle than any beast of the field which the Lord God had made. And he said unto the woman, Yea, hath God said, Ye shall not eat of every tree of the garden. And the woman said unto the serpent, We may eat of the fruit of the trees of the garden,
